newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Sabena 1996 loss widens, sees profits 1998.
newsitem.headline: Sabena 1996 loss widens, sees profits 1998.

text.p: Belgian national airline Sabena said on Wednesday its consolidated loss after provisions widened sharply in 1996, but it still expected to return to profitability in 1998.

The airline, which is 49.5 percent owned by Swissair, said it made a consolidated loss after provisions of 8.87 billion Belgian francs ($251.7 million), up from a 1.66 billion loss in 1995. Exceptional charges totalled 4.1 billion francs.
Operating income rose to 60.63 billion francs to 59.35 billion.

The Belgian carrier said in a statement the cooperation with Swissair , Delta Airlines, Austrian Airlines , Virgin Express, Finnair and Tyrolean was strengthened and should show its full effect from 1997.
It added that synergies with Swissair would yield 600 million Belgian francs for Sabena in 1997.
The results of synergies in general would continue to improve as the collaboration with various companies within the Swissair group increased.
"The above developments, which all derive from a radical company restructuring, should provide a firm foundation for restoring Sabena to profitability in 1998," it said.
Initial results for 1997 suggested that traffic was picking up well, it said. Figures showed a 17 percent improvement compared with the same period last year. ($ = 35.24 Belgian Francs)
